taskDescription: Define and implement VirtEngine end-to-end: a Cosmos-SDK-based hybrid blockchain with (1) decentralized identity verification (VEID) producing an on-chain identity trust score, (2) on-chain MFA gating for sensitive transactions, (3) an on-chain Cloud Marketplace integrated with Waldur and encrypted sensitive payloads, (4) Provider Daemon(s) that bid on orders, provision workloads via orchestration APIs (Kubernetes/SLURM), and record signed usage on-chain, and (5) a decentralized distributed computing 'Supercomputer' via SLURM clusters controlled through blockchain modules and marketplace flows.

projectContext.blockchainFramework: Cosmos SDK (Tendermint consensus, PoS staking validators also operate Identity Network)
primaryLanguages: Golang (Cosmos SDK modules, provider daemon, orchestration adapters)
Python (TensorFlow model training, evaluation, data pipelines)
Django/Python (Waldur services and plugins; existing codebase integration)
repos: virtengine/virtengine (Cosmos chain + custom modules based on virtengine source)

buildCommand.mlTraining: python -m pip install -r requirements.txt && python -m pytest

integration: spin up localnet + waldur via docker compose; run e2e order->bid->provision->usage->settlement
identity upload -> validator decrypt -> ML scoring -> consensus recheck -> score committed

security: All sensitive on-chain payloads use public-key encryption to intended recipient; encrypted in transit & at rest
Approved-client + user file signatures enforced for identity scope uploads
MFA required for configured sensitive transactions (account recovery, processing transactions, key rotation)
reliability: No single point of failure for identity verification or order fulfilment (validator + daemon redundancy)
performance: Identity scoring must complete within block proposal window or use async workflow with on-chain pending->finalized status
Provider daemon must handle burst order events and backpressure orchestration APIs
compliance: Role-based access control + encryption supports privacy constraints while allowing public ledger transparency

coreComponents: On-chain MFA module for sensitive actions
Encryption subsystem (public key encryption; encrypted in transit/at rest; sensitive data never plaintext on public ledger)
Cloud Marketplace (Waldur-backed) with on-chain orders/offerings + encrypted payloads
Provider Daemon (bids, provisions via orchestration APIs like Kubernetes/SLURM, records usage on-chain with signatures)
Staking network (validators also operate Identity Network and recompute identity verification during consensus)
sensitiveDataExamples: owned organizations, team members, audit logs

outcomes: Single source of truth architecture, threat model, and module boundaries
Local devnet + CI baseline for chain, waldur, portal, daemon

releasePhases.phase: 1 - Chain Foundation (Accounts, Roles, Tokens, Encryption, MFA scaffolding)
outcomes: MFA gating framework wired into transaction routing

releasePhases.phase: 2 - VEID v1 (Identity scopes upload, approved-client signatures, ML scoring, consensus verification)
outcomes: Validators recompute score during consensus and validate file signatures

releasePhases.phase: 3 - Cloud Marketplace v1 (Orders/Offerings, Waldur bridge, encrypted payload flows)
outcomes: Users can place orders; providers can list offerings
Sensitive marketplace payloads encrypted to recipients

releasePhases.phase: 4 - Provider Daemon v1 (Bid engine + Kubernetes provisioning + on-chain usage)
5 - Supercomputer v1 (SLURM clusters via marketplace; HPC jobs accounting)
outcomes: Rewards distribution based on on-chain usage
UI comparisons for users; fraud signals integration
Full UI flows: onboarding, identity, marketplace, HPC, admin moderation

userStories.title: Phase 0 - Define system boundaries, data classifications, and threat model
userStories.description: Create an authoritative architecture + security baseline for VEID + Marketplace + Provider Daemon + Supercomputer, including sensitive data classification and encryption/MFA requirements.
acceptanceCriteria: Architecture doc maps modules: VEID, MFA, Encryption, Marketplace, Provider Daemon, SLURM/HPC, Benchmarking, Role model
Sensitive data list and handling rules are defined (on-chain encrypted; in transit + at rest encrypted)
Threat model includes: key theft, malicious provider, fraudulent identity uploads, replay attacks, validator collusion, rogue approved client
Defines which transactions are 'sensitive' and require MFA gating
Defines SLAs for identity scoring and provisioning state transitions
userStories.notes: Derive requirements from accepted claims: validator decrypt+ML score+write to block; consensus validators recompute and verify approved-client signatures; MFA gating; provider daemon orchestration + on-chain usage; encryption with public key for intended recipient.

userStories.title: Phase 1 - Implement hybrid role model and permissions in chain state

acceptanceCriteria: Chain stores role assignments for GenesisAccount, Administrator, Moderator, Staker/Validator, ServiceProvider, Customer, SupportAgent
GenesisAccount can nominate roles and set account states; administrators can manage states within defined bounds
Role-gated queries and message handlers enforce access restrictions
Audit events emitted on role/state change (on-chain event log)

userStories.title: Phase 1 - Implement on-chain public-key encryption primitives and payload envelope format
userStories.description: Create a canonical encrypted payload structure for all sensitive fields stored on-chain and integrate into module message types.
acceptanceCriteria: Payload envelope supports: recipient public key(s), ciphertext, nonce/iv, algorithm id/version, sender signature
All sensitive fields in orders/offerings/identity scopes/support requests are stored only as encrypted payload envelopes
Encryption applied before writing to state; decryption only possible off-chain by recipient with private key (or by selected validator for identity verification flow)
Transport security enforced for APIs (TLS) and at-rest encryption documented for off-chain stores
userStories.notes: Aligns with requirement: sensitive data encrypted using public key encryption, decryptable only with corresponding private key; encrypted in transit and at rest.

userStories.title: Phase 1 - MFA module scaffolding: factors registry, policies, and transaction gating hooks

acceptanceCriteria: MFA module stores per-account MFA policy configuration and factor enrollments (without storing raw secrets on-chain)

Supports factor combinations policy (e.g., SMS+FIDO2, VEID+FIDO2) and 'trusted browser' reduction rule
Account recovery and key-rotation paths require multiple MFA factors per policy
userStories.notes: MFA requirement is explicitly claimed; implement as chain-enforced gate rather than purely UI-level.

userStories.title: Phase 1 - Token module integration for payments, staking rewards, and settlement hooks

userStories.title: Phase 2 - VEID module: identity scope types, upload transaction, and encrypted storage

Upload tx accepts encrypted scope payloads plus signatures (approved client + user signature) and metadata (salt, device info)

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Validator identity verification pipeline: decrypt scopes and compute ML trust score during block proposal
userStories.description: Implement the block-proposing validator flow for identity verification requests: decrypt uploaded scopes with validator private key, compute identity trust score, and include result in proposed block.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Consensus validator recomputation: deterministic scoring and block vote rules

acceptanceCriteria: Consensus validators re-run identity verification computations on the same decrypted identity data (or validated secure computation path)
Validators compare computed score/status to proposer�s and reject block if mismatch beyond defined tolerance (ideally exact match)
Dataset/model version is included in verification record; validators must run same version to vote
All nodes log verification decision metrics for auditability
userStories.notes: Explicitly required: consensus validators perform identity verification computations using same ML algorithms and trained dataset; commit score upon consensus.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - ML pipeline v1: training dataset ingestion, preprocessing, evaluation, and export

Model evaluation outputs repeatable metrics; model artifacts are versioned and reproducible

userStories.title: Phase 2 - TensorFlow-Go inference integration in Cosmos module

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Identity score persistence and query APIs

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Mobile capture protocol v1: salt-binding + anti-gallery replay

Define which actions are 'Authorization-sensitive' (high-value purchases, key rotation, recovery, provider registration, withdrawals)
Document how VEID score (0-100) impacts gating and which minimum thresholds apply to which action categories

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Identity Wallet primitive: user-controlled identity bundle + key binding

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Capture UX v1: guided document + selfie capture (quality checks + feedback loop)
userStories.description: Build the first-pass capture experience (portal/Waldur-integrated and/or approved mobile capture client) with image quality validation and user feedback guidance before upload.
acceptanceCriteria: Client UX provides capture guidance (flat surface, lighting, parallel camera, preview/crop/rotate/retake)
Quality validation implemented client-side and/or server-side: minimum resolution, brightness/contrast range, skew/perspective check (edge/line detection), and blur/noise detection
If validation fails, user receives actionable feedback and must re-capture
Metadata stripping is performed on captured images prior to encryption/upload (EXIF/GPS removed)

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Facial verification pipeline v1: DeepFace-based compare + decision thresholds
userStories.description: Implement face verification using a pretrained DeepFace model (or equivalent) with deterministic version pinning, producing similarity scores and pass/fail decisions.
acceptanceCriteria: Pipeline supports: selfie/live camera frames vs (a) extracted ID-document face and/or (b) previously enrolled face reference
Preprocessing steps implemented explicitly or via library: standard resolution, optional grayscale, histogram equalization (CLAHE), noise reduction, face detect/align/crop, normalization
Verification outputs: similarity score, confidence %, chosen model name/version, and decision (match/no-match)
Decision engine supports configurable thresholds (e.g., 90% match) and emits reason codes for failure/borderline cases
Determinism controls: pin exact container image + model weights hash; enforce CPU-only deterministic ops; record model hash in verification record
Unit tests cover: boundary thresholds, invalid images, no-face-detected, and deterministic repeated runs
userStories.notes: The report explicitly proposes DeepFace and threshold-based decision-making with fallback mechanisms.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Borderline identity fallback: trigger secondary verification (MFA/biometric/OTP)
userStories.description: When facial verification confidence is borderline, require a secondary factor path rather than hard failing identity verification.
acceptanceCriteria: Define 'borderline band' around the primary threshold (e.g., 85�90%) and store it in chain params
If borderline, verification status becomes 'NeedsAdditionalFactor' (not Rejected) and requires an MFA challenge to proceed
Supported fallback challenges: OTP (email/SMS) and/or biometric factor (FIDO2/WebAuthn) depending on enrolled factors
Chain records an auditable event showing fallback triggered and which factor class satisfied it (without storing secrets)
Integration test: borderline face match -> MFA challenge -> verified outcome
userStories.notes: This directly mirrors the report�s recommended fallback mechanisms for near-threshold cases.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - ID document preprocessing v1: standardization, orientation, perspective correction
userStories.description: Implement the document preprocessing pipeline needed for reliable OCR and region detection.
acceptanceCriteria: Standardize format (e.g., PNG) and size/resolution inputs for downstream detection
Apply brightness/contrast normalization (histogram equalization / CLAHE) and sharpness enhancement where needed
Apply noise reduction (Gaussian/median/bilateral) and perspective correction using corner detection + four-point transform
Detect and correct orientation by scanning rotations; choose angle with best face/text detection probability
Outputs a canonical 'normalized_document_image' artifact (not stored plaintext on-chain; only encrypted or derived features)
userStories.notes: Matches the report�s detailed preprocessing and rotation/perspective steps.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Text ROI detection v1: CRAFT integration
userStories.description: Integrate CRAFT (Character-Region Awareness for Text detection) to identify text regions of interest (ROI) in identity documents before OCR.
acceptanceCriteria: CRAFT inference identifies character boxes + affinity scores and produces word/line ROI bounding boxes
ROI outputs include bounding boxes + confidence and are linked to the canonical normalized document image
Post-processing includes thresholding and non-max suppression to stabilize detections
ROI outputs are versioned and reproducible; suite version recorded with verification record
Unit tests cover ROI stability on representative sample documents
userStories.notes: The report explicitly proposes CRAFT for ROI detection prior to OCR.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - OCR extraction v1: Tesseract on ROIs + structured field parsing
userStories.description: Run Tesseract OCR on detected ROIs and parse document fields into structured outputs used by the identity scoring system.
acceptanceCriteria: Each ROI is cropped precisely (rect-sub-pix or equivalent), converted to grayscale, and thresholded for OCR
Tesseract configuration supports doc types and limited character sets (whitelists) where applicable
Post-processing corrects predictable OCR errors and extracts structured fields (e.g., name, surname, DOB, ID number) with confidence scores
Store only hashed/derived field values on-chain (or encrypted field values if needed), never plaintext PII
Unit tests cover parsing and common OCR failure cases
userStories.notes: The report recommends ROI cropping + Tesseract + post-processing to structure extracted identity fields.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Face extraction from ID document v1: U-Net segmentation
userStories.description: Extract the face region from an identity document image using a U-Net segmentation model to enable selfie-to-ID matching.
acceptanceCriteria: U-Net model inference produces a segmentation mask for the face region
Post-process mask into a clean binary face region using dilation/erosion and thresholding
Compute bounding box from mask and crop the ID face ROI reliably across supported doc templates
Export extracted ID-face ROI as an encrypted artifact or derive embeddings immediately and discard raw image per minimization policy
Unit tests cover segmentation success/failure and mask robustness on varied lighting/quality
userStories.notes: The report details U-Net-based segmentation specifically for face extraction from ID documents.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Derived-feature minimization: store embeddings/hashes instead of raw biometrics
userStories.description: Reduce sensitive exposure by retaining derived features (face embeddings, document field hashes) and minimizing retention of raw images where possible.
acceptanceCriteria: Face pipeline produces embeddings and stores only (a) embedding hash on-chain and (b) encrypted embedding payload to intended recipients where required
Raw captured images are not stored on-chain in plaintext; if stored off-chain, they must be encrypted and retention-limited
Verification record references the derived features used (hashes) so validators can recompute consistently
Data lifecycle rules define when raw artifacts are discarded and how derived features are retained
Security review confirms no PII/biometric images leak to logs or public chain state
userStories.notes: Matches the report�s minimization/feature extraction guidance.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Storage architecture for identity artifacts: encrypted off-chain + on-chain references
userStories.description: Implement a scalable storage strategy for identity artifacts that respects blockchain size constraints: encrypted off-chain storage (Waldur DB and/or IPFS) with on-chain content-addressed references.
acceptanceCriteria: Define artifact store interface supporting: put/get by content hash, encryption envelope, retention tags
Support backend A: Waldur backend DB/object store (encrypted at rest) with authenticated retrieval
Support backend B: IPFS (optional v1) storing encrypted chunks; on-chain stores the CID + envelope metadata
Retrieval reconstructs fragmented artifacts deterministically (chunk ordering defined by CID manifest)
Integration tests demonstrate: upload -> store off-chain -> commit reference on-chain -> validator fetch/decrypt for scoring
userStories.notes: The report explicitly discusses centralized (Waldur DB) and decentralized (IPFS) retrieval approaches and blockchain size constraints.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Deterministic identity verification runtime: pinned containers + reproducible builds
userStories.description: Ensure identity verification computations are deterministic across validators by standardizing the execution environment for DeepFace/CRAFT/Tesseract/U-Net pipelines.
acceptanceCriteria: Provide a single pinned OCI image for the identity pipeline (CPU deterministic) with model weight hashes included
Chain records the pipeline image hash + model hashes in verification record; validators must run identical versions to vote
A conformance test suite verifies deterministic outputs across multiple machines (same inputs -> same outputs)
Provide operational docs for validators: how to install/run the pipeline and verify hashes
Integration test: proposer computes verification -> another validator recomputes and matches exactly
userStories.notes: This bridges the report�s ML choices with your consensus requirement that validators recompute identically.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - VEID scoring model v1: feature fusion from doc OCR + face match + metadata
userStories.description: Formalize the identity trust score (0-100) as a deterministic fusion of evidence: document verification signals, OCR confidence, face similarity, and capture metadata checks.
acceptanceCriteria: Define scoring inputs and weights (versioned): face similarity score, OCR field confidence, doc integrity checks, salt-binding check, liveness/capture checks (if present)
Output score is deterministic with reason codes and evidence summary (non-sensitive)
Score version recorded in verification state; history retains past versions and transitions
Unit tests cover scoring boundaries and invariants (e.g., missing doc -> cap score, missing selfie -> fail or require fallback)
userStories.notes: The report discusses multi-scope verification culminating in a score out of 100.

userStories.title: Phase 3 - Authorization policy: high-value purchase threshold triggers biometric/MFA requirement
userStories.description: Implement the report�s authorization concept: high-stakes operations (e.g., purchase above a user-defined threshold) must require biometric/MFA before the on-chain action is accepted.
acceptanceCriteria: User can configure an 'authorization threshold' policy for purchases/transactions (on-chain param stored in MFA module state)
Marketplace order placement checks threshold and requires additional factors if exceeded
If authorization not satisfied, transaction fails with explicit reason and no partial state changes
Portal/Waldur UX prompts for required factors and submits the appropriate MFA proof flow before order tx
Audit events record which policy triggered and that authorization was satisfied

userStories.title: Phase 2 - SSO verification scope v1: OAuth proof capture + linkage to VEID wallet

acceptanceCriteria: Support at least one SSO provider flow in v1 (Google/Microsoft/Facebook as configured) producing a verifiable linkage record

VEID scoring model can incorporate SSO linkage as an optional signal (versioned weighting)
userStories.notes: The report lists SSO as a VEID scope used for streamlined access and identity confidence.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Domain verification scope v1: provider/org proof-of-domain
userStories.description: Implement domain verification as a VEID scope for providers/organizations, enabling trust for marketplace listings.
acceptanceCriteria: Domain verification workflow supports at least one proof method (DNS TXT or HTTP well-known), producing a signed verification record

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Email verification scope v1: proof of control + anti-replay
userStories.description: Implement email verification as a VEID scope with proof-of-control and replay resistance.

VEID scoring model can incorporate email verification as a low-weight signal
userStories.notes: The report lists email verification as a scope and mentions OTP mechanisms.

userStories.title: Phase 1/2 - Security controls: tokenization/pseudonymization + retention policy enforcement
userStories.description: Implement privacy-by-design controls recommended in the technical report: tokenization/pseudonymization, strict retention, and secure auditing for identity data flows.
acceptanceCriteria: Define and implement retention windows per artifact type (raw images, derived embeddings, OCR outputs) with automated expiry enforcement
Any externally referenced identity artifacts are tokenized (public systems see only non-descriptive tokens, not raw data)

Security tests validate: metadata stripping, no PII leakage, retention deletion runs

userStories.title: Phase 2 - VEID integration into Waldur: upload UI + service hooks (if Waldur is used as capture path)

Waldur backend integrates with approved-client signing and encrypts payloads before sending on-chain

userStories.title: Phase 1/2 - Quantum risk posture: cryptography agility plan for VEID envelopes
userStories.description: Add cryptography agility so VEID encryption/signature algorithms can be upgraded (including post-quantum options) without breaking chain state.
acceptanceCriteria: Encryption envelope includes algorithm id/version and supports multiple schemes under a single abstraction
Key rotation procedures include algorithm migration steps (old+new valid during transition window)
Document a roadmap for post-quantum readiness (design-level in v1, implementation in vNext)
Unit tests confirm envelope parsing works across algorithm versions
userStories.notes: The report discusses future quantum risks and the need for post-quantum cryptography planning.

userStories.title: Phase 0 - TEE security model for VEID consensus verification
userStories.description: Define the Trusted Execution Environment (TEE) threat model and the consensus-safe design for enclave-only decryption and scoring, including which TEEs are supported (e.g., SGX, SEV-SNP) and the trust assumptions.
acceptanceCriteria: Threat model explicitly covers: malicious host OS, validator operator compromise, side-channel classes, replay attacks, enclave rollback, and attestation forgery
Define what 'never accessible by general code' means operationally (no plaintext in host memory, logs, IPC payloads, or disk; enclave boundary enforced)
Define the minimum enclave guarantees required for mainnet (remote attestation, sealed keys, measurement allowlist, debug disablement)
Define validator slashing/penalty policy triggers for enclave misbehavior (invalid attestation, missing recomputation, inconsistent scores)
Update architecture diagram: chain modules <-> enclave runtime boundary <-> ML pipeline
userStories.notes: This is the baseline requirement to reconcile claim language ('decrypts with private key') with enclave-only decryption.

userStories.title: Phase 1 - On-chain Enclave Registry module for validator identity processing
userStories.description: Implement a Cosmos module to register and query validator VEID enclave identities (attestation + keys) so clients can encrypt identity payloads specifically to enclave public keys.
acceptanceCriteria: State stores per-validator enclave identity record: enclave_measurement_hash, enclave_enc_pubkey, enclave_sign_pubkey, attestation_quote, attestation_chain, epoch/expiry
MsgRegisterEnclaveIdentity only executable by validator operator key; updates are audited via events
Governance-controlled allowlist of approved enclave measurements (and optional minimum TEE version constraints)
Queries support: get active validator enclave keys, get committee subset keys (if committee mode enabled), get measurement allowlist
Validation rejects: expired attestations, non-allowlisted measurements, malformed quote chains
userStories.notes: This is required for encrypting identity data to the trusted execution env rather than to a general-purpose node key.

userStories.title: Phase 1 - Encrypted envelope upgrade: multi-recipient encryption for validator enclaves
userStories.description: Extend the encrypted payload envelope format to support encrypting identity data to the enclave keys of multiple validators (so each can recompute within TEE during consensus).
acceptanceCriteria: Envelope supports: payload_ciphertext + per-recipient wrapped_key entries (recipient_id -> wrapped_key) and algorithm/version metadata
Recipient list supports either: (A) full active validator set, or (B) designated identity committee subset (configurable)
Envelope includes sender signatures (approved client + user) as already required
Serialization format is deterministic and consensus-safe (stable ordering, canonical encoding)
Unit tests: same inputs produce identical envelope bytes across platforms
userStories.notes: Consensus validators must recompute; they can only do so if payloads are encrypted to their enclaves.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Enclave Runtime v1: decrypt+score API with sealed keys (no plaintext escape)
userStories.description: Implement the VEID enclave service that receives ciphertext, performs decryption and ML scoring inside the enclave, and returns only an enclave-signed result (score/status/evidence hashes).
acceptanceCriteria: Enclave generates its decryption private key inside enclave and seals it; host cannot export it
Host-side code can only submit ciphertext + metadata; enclave returns score/status + reason codes + evidence hashes + enclave signature
Enclave scrubs plaintext buffers after use; no debug logging of sensitive content; deny-by-default for any host read primitives
Enclave exposes bounded runtime controls (timeouts, max input sizes) to protect block proposal windows
Integration test verifies: plaintext never appears outside enclave boundary (no host memory buffers, no logs, no disk writes)
userStories.notes: This is the concrete implementation of 'identity data remains sandboxed'.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Attested scoring output: include enclave signature + measurement linkage in block
userStories.description: Require that every identity score written into a proposed block carries an enclave-signed attestation payload proving it was computed inside an approved enclave measurement.
acceptanceCriteria: VEID verification record stored on-chain includes: score/status, model/version hashes, enclave_measurement_hash, enclave_signed_result, attestation_reference (or quote hash)
Consensus validation checks that enclave_measurement_hash is allowlisted and corresponds to registered validator enclave identity
Reject block if: missing enclave signature, invalid signature, measurement not allowlisted, or attestation expired
Events emitted: VEIDScoreComputedAttested, VEIDScoreRejectedAttestation
userStories.notes: Makes proposer scoring verifiable without revealing plaintext identity data.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Consensus recomputation inside enclave: vote rule enforcement
userStories.description: Update consensus verification path so validators recompute identity scores by calling their own enclave runtime and reject blocks with mismatched results.
acceptanceCriteria: When proposed block contains VEID verification record, validator retrieves ciphertext and runs enclave recomputation locally (using its wrapped_key entry)
Validator compares recomputed score/status to proposer�s values and rejects block on mismatch (exact match required unless tolerance is explicitly defined)
Validator also verifies approved-client + user signatures as per claim requirements
Determinism strategy is enforced: pinned model/container hashes recorded and required for vote eligibility
Integration test: proposer computes score -> another validator recomputes inside enclave -> votes only if equal
userStories.notes: Directly implements the accepted claim�s 'consensus validators perform identity verification computations using the same ML algorithms and trained dataset'.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Key lifecycle: enclave key rotation, epoching, and re-encryption policy
userStories.description: Implement operational key lifecycle for validator enclaves, including rotation, expiry, and how clients select keys for encryption without breaking ongoing pending verifications.
acceptanceCriteria: Validators can rotate enclave keys via MsgRotateEnclaveIdentity with overlap window (old+new valid for configured epochs)
Clients can query 'current valid key set' for the validator set/committee and include only those recipients
Define and implement behavior when validator set changes (new validators added): committee mode or key set update rules
Slashing/penalty conditions defined for validators that cannot recompute due to missing enclave availability
Docs: validator operator runbook for enclave updates and key rotation
userStories.notes: Without explicit lifecycle rules, 'encrypted to validator TEEs' becomes operationally brittle.

userStories.title: Phase 2 - Privacy and leakage controls: forbid plaintext identity material in host logs/telemetry
userStories.description: Hard enforce 'no plaintext outside enclave' with code-level safeguards and CI checks across chain, bridge, and any identity services.
acceptanceCriteria: Structured logging redaction rules added; encrypted blobs truncated; no dumps of request bodies
Static checks/linters fail builds if forbidden logging patterns exist in VEID path
Fuzz tests inject malformed identity payloads and confirm no error path leaks plaintext
Security test: memory inspection harness confirms no plaintext buffers in host process after enclave call returns
Incident procedure documented for suspected leakage
userStories.notes: Turns the requirement into enforceable engineering gates.

userStories.title: Phase 3 - Marketplace on-chain data model: offerings, orders, allocations, and states
userStories.description: Define on-chain marketplace objects with explicit state machines for offerings and orders, with encrypted sensitive fields.
acceptanceCriteria: Offerings include: provider id, public metadata, pricing, required identity level, encrypted provider secrets as needed
Orders include: customer id, offering id, public metadata, encrypted configuration, lifecycle states
Allocation record maps order -> selected provider upon acceptance/bid win
All sensitive fields are stored as encrypted payload envelopes
userStories.notes: Accepted claims: orders and provider offerings include sensitive data stored encrypted for intended recipient; access depends on identification system.

userStories.title: Phase 3 - Marketplace gating: identity score requirement enforcement
userStories.description: Enforce that certain offerings require verified identity status/score and block non-verified purchases.
acceptanceCriteria: Offering can declare minimum identity score/status requirement
Order creation checks identity score/status and rejects if insufficient
UI/API surfaces reason and required steps to meet verification requirement
Providers can optionally require verified identity for all their offerings
userStories.notes: Explicitly claimed: marketplace enforces only accounts with verified identity may obtain certain offerings.

userStories.title: Phase 3 - Marketplace sensitive action gating via MFA module
userStories.description: Integrate MFA checks into marketplace lifecycle actions (place order, approve/modify order, cancel, key rotation, withdrawal/settlement).
acceptanceCriteria: Sensitive marketplace actions invoke MFA verification according to account policy
Trusted browser rule reduces required factors where applicable
MFA audit trail is recorded on-chain for each gated action
Failure states are explicit and do not create partial order state corruption
userStories.notes: MFA gating is an on-chain requirement; not just UI.

userStories.title: Phase 3 - Waldur bridge module: synchronize public ledger data into Waldur and route actions back on-chain
userStories.description: Implement a Cosmos module + service that syncs providers/users/offerings/orders public data to Waldur and listens to Waldur events to update on-chain state.
acceptanceCriteria: Public ledger exports: offerings, public order state, provider profiles into Waldur
Waldur actions (provision, terminate, service desk ticket) create signed callbacks/events that translate into on-chain transactions
Bridge is idempotent and resilient (replay-safe, at-least-once processing without duplication)
Sensitive details remain encrypted on-chain and are only decrypted by intended recipients or provider daemon
userStories.notes: Spec: run Waldur as separate system, communicate via API; chain stores public info; sensitive data encrypted.

userStories.title: Phase 3 - Marketplace eventing: order created/allocated/updated emits daemon-consumable events
userStories.description: Define chain events for provider daemon consumption and build subscription mechanism (RPC/WebSocket).
acceptanceCriteria: Events emitted: OrderCreated, BidPlaced, AllocationCreated, ProvisionRequested, TerminateRequested, UsageUpdateRequested
Event payloads include only non-sensitive identifiers; sensitive data referenced via encrypted envelopes
Provider daemon can subscribe and resume from checkpoints
Tests cover event replay and idempotent handling
userStories.notes: Provider daemon must react to won leases/manifests per spec.

userStories.title: Phase 4 - Provider Daemon: key management and transaction signing
userStories.description: Implement provider daemon signing for bids, status updates, and usage records, verifiable using provider public key.
acceptanceCriteria: Daemon supports provider key storage strategy (hardware/ledger/non-custodial integration as feasible)
All on-chain submissions from daemon are signed and verifiable via provider public key
Chain verifies daemon signature on usage/status records
Rotation procedure exists without breaking verification
userStories.notes: Accepted claims: provider daemon returns digitally signed workload status/usage record verifiable using provider public key.

userStories.title: Phase 4 - Provider Daemon: bid engine and provider configuration watcher
userStories.description: Implement daemon that queries orders and places bids based on provider pricing/config; updates dynamically without restart.
acceptanceCriteria: Daemon reads provider config from on-chain state (pricing, capacity, supported offering types)
Bids are placed automatically for matching orders and recorded on-chain
Config updates are detected and applied at runtime
Rate limits and anti-spam rules prevent runaway bidding
userStories.notes: Spec describes bid engine and dynamic config updates.

userStories.title: Phase 4 - Provider Daemon: manifest parsing and validation
userStories.description: Implement manifest schema(s) for provisioning requests and validate before invoking orchestration APIs.
acceptanceCriteria: Manifest supports: VM/container specs, networking, storage, tags, region/latency constraints, lifecycle hooks
Validation rejects unsupported parameters and records reason on-chain
Manifests can be versioned; daemon supports at least v1
Unit tests cover edge cases and backward compatibility
userStories.notes: Spec references manifest parsing and deployment on behalf of users.

userStories.title: Phase 4 - Provider Daemon: Kubernetes orchestration adapter (v1)
userStories.description: Provision workloads via Kubernetes API (as first orchestration integration) upon allocation events.
acceptanceCriteria: Daemon can instantiate workload from manifest into Kubernetes (namespaced, least-privileged RBAC)
Daemon can terminate workloads and clean up resources
Daemon reports status transitions back on-chain (Provisioning -> Running -> Terminating -> Terminated/Failed)
Secrets handling: decrypted only as required; never logged; stored encrypted at rest on provider side
userStories.notes: Accepted claims require orchestration API such as Kubernetes or SLURM.

userStories.title: Phase 4 - Provider Daemon: usage metering + on-chain recording
userStories.description: Track resource usage and post signed usage records to chain for settlement.
acceptanceCriteria: Usage schema includes: order id, time window, cpu/mem/storage/network, job id (if applicable), pricing calc inputs
Usage record is signed by provider daemon key and verifiable on-chain
Periodic updates and final settlement record on termination are supported
Fraud checks: reject impossible usage deltas; flag anomalies for moderation
userStories.notes: Accepted claims: track and record usage of allocated resources on blockchain; settlement upon termination.

userStories.title: Phase 5 - SLURM cluster lifecycle module: define HPC offering type and job accounting schema
userStories.description: Introduce HPC offerings and job lifecycle objects in marketplace and chain state.
acceptanceCriteria: HPC offering includes: queue/partition options, pricing, required identity threshold, max runtime, preconfigured workloads list
Job request object includes: container/image, command, resources, data references, encrypted inputs/outputs pointers
Job accounting schema supports rewards distribution and billing
userStories.notes: Spec/claims: HPC module includes library of pre-configured workloads + custom workloads support.

userStories.title: Phase 5 - SLURM orchestration adapter in Provider Daemon (v1)
userStories.description: Extend provider daemon to schedule workloads via SLURM for distributed computing / supercomputer use cases.
acceptanceCriteria: Daemon can submit SLURM jobs on allocation event and track job id and status
Daemon reports job status and usage metrics on-chain with signature
Supports cancellation/termination with on-chain state integrity
Handles batch scheduling across selected nodes
userStories.notes: Accepted claims: schedule workload via SLURM on selected nodes; record usage; distribute rewards.

userStories.title: Phase 5 - Decentralized SLURM cluster deployment via Kubernetes (bootstrap)
userStories.description: Implement the cluster bootstrap automation: deploy SLURM controllers/workers across Kubernetes clusters and register into marketplace.
acceptanceCriteria: SLURM cluster templates can be deployed via Kubernetes manifests/Helm
Nodes can join/leave without breaking scheduling; resilience documented
Cluster registration posts public metadata to chain; sensitive config encrypted
Integration tests: deploy cluster -> submit job -> observe completion and accounting
userStories.notes: Spec describes SLURM deployed across Kubernetes clusters; workload nodes added to existing clusters.

userStories.title: Phase 5 - Proximity-based mini-supercomputer clustering (v1 heuristic)
userStories.description: Implement first-pass clustering logic for grouping closely connected nodes by latency/region and scheduling HPC tasks accordingly.
acceptanceCriteria: Node metadata includes region + latency measurements (from benchmarking/daemon)
Scheduler prefers low-latency clusters for eligible jobs
Fallback routing exists when preferred cluster is saturated
Recorded decision trail for scheduling is queryable
userStories.notes: Spec describes clustering closely connected systems to build mini-supercomputers within distributed network.

userStories.title: Phase 5 - Rewards distribution for HPC contributors based on on-chain usage
userStories.description: Distribute VE token rewards to nodes/providers for HPC workloads using metered usage records.
acceptanceCriteria: Reward formula documented and implemented deterministically
Rewards issuance references signed usage records and job completion status
Disputes/anomalies can be flagged for moderation
Unit tests cover edge cases (partial failures, retries, termination mid-job)
userStories.notes: Claimed: distribute rewards in tokens to contributing nodes based on on-chain usage data.

userStories.title: Phase 6 - Benchmarking daemon: provider performance metrics collection
userStories.description: Implement a benchmarking daemon that measures provider cluster performance (compute, memory, disk, network, latency) and publishes signed benchmark results to the blockchain as transparent trust signals for marketplace discovery and scheduling.
acceptanceCriteria: Benchmarking daemon runs as a provider-managed agent (container/systemd) with configurable schedule and on-demand challenge runs triggered by chain events

Collected metrics include at minimum: CPU (single/multi-core), memory bandwidth/latency, disk IO (read/write IOPS + throughput), network throughput + RTT/latency to reference endpoints, and optional GPU metrics when present
Each benchmark report includes: provider id, cluster id, node/region metadata, test suite version, timestamp, raw metric values, and a normalized summary score
Benchmark report is digitally signed by the provider benchmarking key and verifiable on-chain using the provider�s registered public key
Reports are posted to chain via a dedicated message type (e.g., MsgSubmitBenchmarks) and indexed for query by provider/offering/region
Daemon never logs or transmits any secrets; any configuration secrets used to reach endpoints are kept provider-side and encrypted at rest
Backpressure and retry logic prevents runaway submissions during network issues and ensures idempotent posting (same report hash cannot be submitted twice)
Unit tests cover metric parsing, signing/verification, idempotency, and error paths; integration test demonstrates posting metrics to devnet and querying them
userStories.notes: Benchmarking is a first-class marketplace trust signal and must be transparent and verifiable on-chain.

userStories.title: Phase 6 - Benchmarking on-chain module: metric schema, verification, and retention
userStories.description: Create/extend a Cosmos module to store benchmark reports, verify signatures, apply retention rules, and expose query APIs for marketplace ranking and scheduling decisions.
acceptanceCriteria: Defines canonical metric schema with versioning, including raw metrics + computed aggregates and suite metadata
Verifies benchmark report signatures using the provider public key registered in provider state
Rejects malformed reports, unknown providers, invalid signatures, or out-of-bounds metric values (basic sanity limits)
Supports retention policy: keep rolling window of N reports per cluster/offering type; older reports pruned deterministically
Emits events: BenchmarksSubmitted, BenchmarksRejected, BenchmarksPruned
Query endpoints support: list providers by region/metric, get provider history, get offering-scoped benchmark summaries
All benchmark data stored on-chain is non-sensitive; any sensitive endpoints or internal node addresses must be excluded or encrypted if required
Unit tests cover state transitions, pruning determinism, signature verification, and query correctness
userStories.notes: Keep schema stable and explicitly versioned to avoid breaking UI and ranking logic.

userStories.title: Phase 6 - Marketplace trust signals: provider reliability score computation
userStories.description: Compute an on-chain (or deterministic off-chain but chain-verifiable) provider reliability score that blends benchmark results, uptime/incident signals, fulfillment success rate, and dispute rates to inform marketplace ordering and eligibility.
acceptanceCriteria: Reliability score inputs are explicitly defined and deterministic: benchmark summary, provisioning success rate, mean time to provision, mean time between failures, dispute/anomaly flags
Score computation is reproducible and versioned (score_version stored with each computed score)
Score updates occur on benchmark submission and on major lifecycle events (provision success/fail, termination, dispute resolved)
Providers can query their score breakdown and contributing factors
Marketplace listing pages can request ranking keys (score + benchmarks) without requiring decryption of any sensitive payloads
Moderators/admins can flag providers to exclude from ranking (policy-based), with an auditable on-chain record
Unit tests validate deterministic computation and guard against division-by-zero, missing metrics, and extreme values
userStories.notes: This is a trust layer; keep the formula transparent and verifiable.

userStories.title: Phase 6 - Benchmark challenge protocol: anti-gaming and anomaly detection hooks
userStories.description: Add anti-gaming mechanisms: randomized challenge benchmarks, cross-validation, and anomaly flags that can be reviewed by moderators and used to reduce provider rank.
acceptanceCriteria: Chain can emit BenchmarkChallengeRequested events targeting a provider/offering/cluster with a required suite version and deadline
Provider daemon/benchmarking daemon can execute the challenge suite and submit results signed by provider benchmarking key
On-chain validation checks freshness (deadline), suite hash/version, and signature integrity
Anomaly rules flag suspicious results (e.g., sudden unrealistic jumps, inconsistent CPU/memory ratios, repeated identical outputs) without blocking normal marketplace operations
Flags are recorded as on-chain events and exposed via query APIs for UI and moderation workflows
Providers can respond with an explanation artifact reference (encrypted to moderators) without disclosing secrets publicly
Integration test: challenge -> submit -> anomaly flag -> moderator review path is exercised end-to-end
userStories.notes: Keep enforcement non-destructive initially: flag and rank-reduce before hard bans.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Portal foundation: authentication, wallets, and session model
userStories.description: Implement the portal�s core auth flows for wallet-based login and optional SSO-based login, with secure session handling and chain RPC client integration.
acceptanceCriteria: Portal supports wallet-based login (mnemonic/keypair) and establishes a signed session token for UI operations
Optional SSO login flow is supported where applicable and maps to a blockchain account binding flow
Session tokens are stored securely (httpOnly cookies or equivalent) and rotated; logout invalidates session
Portal integrates with chain RPC/WebSocket for event subscriptions and query APIs
All network traffic uses TLS; no sensitive material is ever logged client-side
Unit tests cover auth state machine; e2e test validates login -> fetch account profile -> subscribe to events
userStories.notes: Portal must be functional without exposing private keys; prefer non-custodial signing via wallet adapters where possible.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Portal: VEID onboarding, identity score display, and re-verification prompts
userStories.description: Implement portal screens for identity onboarding: status, score, required scopes, and guided workflows that deep-link to the approved capture client(s).
acceptanceCriteria: Portal shows identity status (Unknown/Pending/Verified/Rejected) and score (0-100) with model version metadata
Portal lists required scopes per marketplace action (e.g., provider registration, high-trust offerings) and links to approved client capture instructions
Portal displays upload history and verification record summaries without revealing encrypted scope contents
When verification is Pending/Failed, portal shows reason codes and recommended next steps
Identity gating errors from marketplace/order flows are surfaced with clear remediation paths
Unit tests cover UI state mapping; e2e test verifies identity query -> status render -> gating message
userStories.notes: Identity scoring and status are on-chain and must be treated as the source of truth.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Portal: MFA enrollment, policy configuration, and trusted browser UX
userStories.description: Build portal UX for MFA: factor enrollment, policy configuration, trusted browser registration, and transaction-level prompts for MFA-gated actions.
acceptanceCriteria: Portal supports enrollment flows for multiple factor types (e.g., OTP app, FIDO2/WebAuthn, SMS where supported, VEID biometric where supported)
Portal allows configuring MFA policies (required factor combinations) and shows which transaction types are considered sensitive
Trusted browser flow is supported and clearly indicates reduced-factor behavior; user can revoke trusted browsers
When a user attempts a sensitive action, portal prompts for required factors and only then submits the on-chain transaction
Portal displays an audit/history view of MFA-gated actions (from on-chain events)
Unit tests cover policy editing and factor states; e2e test covers a gated marketplace action requiring MFA
userStories.notes: MFA gating is enforced by chain rules; portal must reflect chain responses faithfully.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Portal: marketplace discovery, offering details, and checkout
userStories.description: Implement the marketplace UI: browse offerings, compare providers using benchmark trust signals, place orders, and manage order lifecycle states.
acceptanceCriteria: Marketplace list view supports filters (region, price, identity requirement, benchmark score) and sorting (reliability score, price, latency)
Offering detail view shows public metadata and clearly identifies which fields are encrypted/sensitive
Checkout flow validates identity score requirements before submitting an order transaction
Order details view shows lifecycle state transitions and chain events (created, bid placed, allocated, provisioning, running, terminated, failed)
Encrypted payloads are never displayed unless the viewer is the intended recipient and can decrypt locally; otherwise show placeholders
E2E test covers: browse -> select -> order -> observe events -> see allocation -> see provisioning state updates
userStories.notes: Use benchmark metrics to drive user decision-making and to support proximity-aware HPC scheduling UX.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Portal: provider console (offerings, pricing, capacity, domain verification)
userStories.description: Create provider-facing portal capabilities: register as provider, perform domain verification, manage offerings, pricing, and monitor bids/allocations/usage and settlements.
acceptanceCriteria: Provider registration flow enforces identity + domain verification requirements before enabling marketplace listing
Provider can create/edit/publish offerings with identity gating requirements and public metadata
Provider can set pricing/capacity parameters and see them reflected in provider daemon configuration/state
Provider can monitor incoming orders, bids placed by daemon, allocations won/lost, and workload status
Provider can view usage records and settlement summaries, with drill-down to signed usage report hashes
E2E test covers: provider registers -> creates offering -> customer orders -> provider wins -> usage visible
userStories.notes: Provider operational transparency is key for marketplace adoption.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Portal: Supercomputer/HPC UI (job submission, library workloads, outputs)
userStories.description: Implement the HPC portal UX: browse preconfigured workloads, submit SLURM-backed jobs, track progress, and access outputs via encrypted references.
acceptanceCriteria: Users can select a preconfigured workload template (v1 library) or submit a custom job manifest (v1 schema)
Job submission checks identity + MFA gating policies as required and posts a job request to chain
Portal tracks job status via chain events (queued, running, completed, failed, cancelled) and displays timestamps
Outputs are represented as encrypted pointers/references; only the job owner can decrypt and retrieve details
Users can cancel jobs; cancellation state is consistent across chain, provider daemon, and SLURM adapter
Integration test covers: submit -> schedule -> complete -> usage recorded -> rewards/settlement visible
userStories.notes: Keep outputs off-chain except encrypted references; never leak sensitive payloads in UI logs.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Admin & moderation portal: roles, account states, offering controls, and audit trails
userStories.description: Deliver admin and moderator tooling to manage roles, account states (active/suspended/terminated), offering states, dispute flags, and on-chain audit trails.
acceptanceCriteria: Genesis/admin users can assign roles and change account states with full audit events and reason codes
Moderators can review anomaly flags (benchmarks, usage anomalies, identity fraud signals) and escalate actions
Admins can pause/unlist offerings and providers, with explicit state transitions and on-chain events
SupportAgent role can access assigned support workflows without accessing unrelated sensitive payloads
Portal provides audit log viewer (event-indexed) with robust filtering and export (non-sensitive only)
E2E test covers: admin changes account state -> user blocked -> audit event visible -> rollback possible per policy
userStories.notes: Even administrators should not be able to read encrypted payloads unless they are the intended recipient.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Support requests end-to-end: encrypted tickets + Waldur service desk integration
userStories.description: Implement support request flows where ticket content is encrypted on-chain, synchronized to Waldur service desk, and accessible only to authorized parties.
acceptanceCriteria: Customer can create a support request referencing an order/resource; sensitive ticket body is encrypted to the intended recipient(s)
SupportAgent and provider can respond; responses are stored encrypted and linked to ticket thread state on-chain
Waldur bridge syncs public ticket metadata and state changes while keeping sensitive ticket bodies encrypted
Moderators can access only tickets they are authorized to handle (role + intended recipient encryption)
E2E test covers: create ticket -> provider reply -> state sync -> customer reads reply (decrypt locally)
userStories.notes: Tickets are explicitly listed as sensitive data and must remain encrypted.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Observability: chain, bridge, daemons, and orchestration adapters
userStories.description: Implement unified observability (metrics, logs, traces) across chain nodes, Waldur bridge, provider daemon(s), benchmarking daemon(s), and orchestration adapters.
acceptanceCriteria: Standardized structured logging across Go services and Python services with correlation IDs (order id, job id, tx hash)
Prometheus metrics exported for: chain performance, mempool, VEID verification timings, provider daemon bid/provision throughput, benchmark submission rate
Tracing across portal -> API -> chain tx submission -> daemon handlers where feasible
Dashboards include SLO views: identity verification latency, order provisioning latency, job completion latency, error budgets
Alert rules: validator health, daemon backlog, failed provisioning spikes, benchmark anomaly spikes
Runbook links included in dashboards
userStories.notes: Do not log plaintext sensitive payloads; scrub/omit encrypted blob contents from logs.

userStories.title: Phase 7 - Operational hardening: idempotent workflows, retries, and safe state machines
userStories.description: Harden all cross-system workflows (chain <-> bridge <-> daemons <-> orchestration) for idempotency, replay-safety, and safe recovery from partial failures.
acceptanceCriteria: All order/job lifecycle handlers are idempotent (replays do not create duplicate resources or double-billing)
Provider daemon persists checkpoints and resumes subscriptions without skipping events
Bridge implements at-least-once delivery with deduplication and replay-safe handlers
Explicit terminal states exist for orders/jobs (Completed/Terminated/Failed/Cancelled) with consistent settlement behavior
Chaos tests simulate: chain restart, daemon restart, network partition, orchestration API timeouts
Post-incident recovery procedures are documented and validated on staging
userStories.notes: This is a GA-critical reliability milestone.

userStories.title: Phase 8 - Security audit readiness: cryptography, key management, and MFA enforcement review
userStories.description: Prepare for third-party security assessment by hardening cryptographic envelope handling, key rotation procedures, and MFA/identity gating enforcement paths.
acceptanceCriteria: Encryption envelope implementations are reviewed and consistent across modules and services; algorithms and versions are documented
Key rotation procedures exist for: provider daemon keys, approved client keys, validator identity keys, user account keys (account recovery flow)
MFA enforcement paths are tested for all designated sensitive transactions (including account recovery and processing transactions)
Identity upload signature checks (approved client + user) are tested and enforced in both proposal and consensus verification paths
Static analysis and dependency scanning pass for Go/Python/TS repos; critical findings resolved or accepted with documented risk
Security test suite includes replay tests, signature forgery tests, and malformed payload tests
userStories.notes: Treat consensus determinism and signature verification as top-tier audit items.

userStories.title: Phase 8 - Load & performance testing: identity scoring throughput, marketplace bursts, and HPC scheduling
userStories.description: Execute load testing across the system to validate performance targets for identity scoring, order throughput, and daemon backpressure behavior.
acceptanceCriteria: Load test scenario A: burst of identity scope uploads -> pending/finalized scoring -> chain stability maintained
Load test scenario B: burst of orders + bids -> allocations -> provisioning events -> consistent on-chain state transitions
Load test scenario C: HPC job submissions -> SLURM scheduling -> accounting updates -> reward distribution
Performance baselines documented: p95 identity verification latency, p95 order provisioning latency, daemon event lag
Resource limits (CPU/memory) defined for daemons and bridge services; backpressure validated
Bottlenecks identified and addressed; regression harness added to CI for critical benchmarks
userStories.notes: Ensure test artifacts are reproducible and can be re-run for future releases.

userStories.title: Phase 8 - Mainnet genesis, validator onboarding, and network parameterization
userStories.description: Deliver mainnet readiness: genesis tooling, validator onboarding guide, and governance-controlled network parameters (including approved client allowlist and fees).
acceptanceCriteria: Genesis generation tool produces deterministic genesis.json with initial roles, parameters, and module configs
Validator onboarding guide covers: staking setup, identity verification responsibilities, model/version pinning, monitoring
Governance/admin parameter controls implemented for: approved client allowlist, MFA-sensitive tx list, fees, retention windows
Upgrade strategy documented (software upgrades, parameter migrations, emergency halts if applicable)
Dry-run ceremony executed on a testnet environment and documented
userStories.notes: Validators also operate the identity network; onboarding must reflect that operational burden.

userStories.title: Phase 8 - Documentation & SDKs: developer, provider, and user guides
userStories.description: Produce comprehensive documentation and client SDKs for interacting with VirtEngine (portal, chain modules, provider daemon integration, and Waldur bridge).
acceptanceCriteria: Developer docs: module APIs, encryption envelope spec, event schema, transaction examples, local devnet instructions
Provider docs: daemon setup, Kubernetes/SLURM adapter configuration, key management, benchmarking setup, dispute handling
User docs: onboarding, VEID process, MFA setup, marketplace purchase flows, HPC job submission
SDKs delivered: TypeScript client for portal + chain, Go client for daemons/services, Python helpers for ML artifacts and integration tests
Docs include security guidance: never expose private keys, payload encryption rules, safe logging practices
Documentation published and versioned with release tags
userStories.notes: Docs are part of GA acceptance; keep them aligned with on-chain schemas and events.

userStories.title: Phase 8 - GA release checklist: SLOs, incident playbooks, and production readiness review
userStories.description: Finalize GA readiness with operational checklists, SLOs, incident playbooks, and production readiness sign-off for each major subsystem.
acceptanceCriteria: SLOs defined for: chain availability, identity scoring pipeline availability, marketplace order fulfillment, HPC job scheduling
Incident playbooks exist for: validator outage, identity scoring failure, provider daemon misbehavior, bridge failure, key compromise
On-call rotation expectations documented; escalation paths defined
Backup/restore plans validated for off-chain components (Waldur DB, portal state) and documented for chain state via standard node procedures
Final production readiness review completed with explicit go/no-go criteria and sign-offs
userStories.notes: GA isn�t only features�operability and recovery matter as much as functionality.

userStories.title: Gap Phase - Mobile capture app: native camera integration
userStories.description: Implement mobile app (iOS/Android) for capturing identity documents and facial biometrics (Patent Claim 2).
acceptanceCriteria: Native mobile app for iOS and Android
Camera with real-time quality feedback
Liveness detection during facial capture
Gallery uploads blocked
Approved-client key signing
